job_title: Event Coordinator in Boca Raton, FL
pros: There is a consistant, steady, reliable work schedule and benefits. If you're looking for flexibility, my particular job/department - this is not it, but looking for a solid 8am-5pm Monday - Friday, no weekends, no nights, do your work get, things are good! It's my first job out from grad school and the people, campus, and community are great.
cons: Not flexible with work schedule. Always some politic-ing.

job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in Boca Raton, FL
pros: Lots of very good people to work with. You can join the campus gym so it's right there when you have time to use it.
cons: You might get run over by a bicycle but other than that there isn't much of a down side beyond that.

review_title: flexible but low-pay and lots of work
job_title: Assistant Community Health Program Representative in Boca Raton, FL
pros: flexible schedules, opportunity to try and learn new skills on the job, benefits are also great
cons: impossible to get a raise and pay is already much lower than what you'd get in a private company

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Boca Raton, FL
pros: You learn a lot from a wide variety of disciplines. People are generally supportive and some jobs have nice benefits.
cons: You have to pay for a parking permit, even if you work on a site away from the main campus. These permits are not cheap.

job_title: Student Assistant II in Sacramento, CA
pros: Flexible scheduling. Bi-Weekly deposit. Located on campus. Straightforward job.
cons: No upward mobility as a student. Menial work here and there. Not good for people who seek a challenge. Typical short term job as a full time student.

pros: Great training for all interests......even outside your career field. Good benefits and flexibility along with great purpose.
cons: Pay is horrible compared to like state jobs not at UC. They offer decent salaries to new hires, but do not appreciate long standing employees with lots of experience, comparable degrees and working knowledge.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Sacramento, CA
pros: There is good and timely pay and benefits at UC Davis, especially in biomedical engineering department compared to others.
cons: The location is far from bigger cities and the opportunities to network are more limited. The recruiting and career networking is not as plentiful as in other major cities.

pros: UC Davis has a host of opportunities to grow, improve, and contribute to projects that are meaningful to you. If you work in a lab, as I did, a lot of your experience will be contingent upon the quality of your Lead PI. Keep that in mind
cons: When working in a scientific capacity, the PI's in charge of you, while excellent scientists, may not be excellent managers.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros:
- Good courses for continued education
- Lots of possibilities for professional & personal development
- Very smart coworkers & great opportunities overall (the main reason why I would recommend)
- Decent support for international students (not the best, but OK)
cons:
- Countless irrelevant emails from administration (5-10 a day)
- Complicated & bad, yet expensive health insurance ( >$5,000 / year)
- They sometimes forget to pay you & you have to follow up

job_title: Ph D Student in Davis, CA
pros: Fun work environment. Profs treat their students like people not laborers. All profs are friendly. Wide variety of research projects because the department is joint with materials science. Stipend is plenty if you are smart.
cons: Old building and many student offices don't have windows. Not convenient to many industries if you have spouse in tech job. Depend insurance coverage is poor.

pros:
Coworkers and management were amazing to work with. The workplace provided training and if you're a student, they also assist with book costs. 
Two other pros: flexible work hours and free food during break if you work in the dining common.
 It's a great place to work as a student if you want some cash and work experience.
cons: The pay could've been better.

review_title: A legitimate institution of learning with (perceived) corruption problems
job_title: Advanced Research Aide & Computer Programmer in Davis, CA
pros: Flexible hours, strong academic tradition, mostly healthy campus culture, good mix of research and teaching professors.
cons: Rock-bottom pay for students, as it's an academic organization. Starts at $11 per hour, jumping to $13 for someone with a bachelor's.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: Make own hours, able to work with different people of many backgrounds, community is safe and friendly, health benefits and retirement plan.
cons: It can get really hot in the summer and really cold in the winter, sometimes students drive bikes recklessly on campus.

pros:
- easy going people
- great science
- nice small town, outgoing and sport oriented. Everything is 30-60 min away.
cons:
- small town
- research focused too much on agricultural fields
- "Davicians" are a bit strange and secluded. They don't want their town to grow and housing prices are similar to bay area
- Postdoc salary sucks, but this is not only in UCD

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Davis, CA
pros:
benefits
time off
social
great to help students
best technology
lots of opportunities to cross train and learn new skills
flexibile schedules
cons:
you are not valued
overworked
not paid what you make in the outside world
limited raises

review_title: Great experience with a world of opportunity!
job_title: Security Systems Programmer in Davis, CA
pros: There is a lot of potential for experience and diversity. You can get what you want by being part of campus social groups that will ultimately get you into higher jobs.
cons: Too many silos of separate realms of control. Each department is under their own management so there is no cohesiveness with central IT.

job_title: Student Assistant III in Davis, CA
pros: Flexible scheduling and paid holidays, excellent corporate culture, supportive and competent management, excellent training opportunities and on-boarding, beautiful campus, team spirit.
cons: Salaries are not competitive, expensive employee parking, bureaucracy, state funding creates constraints on operations, HR and hiring process was drawn out and delayed.

pros:
Great School & Campus. Very nice community.
Has a great downtown, biking around campus is easiest way to get around.
cons:
It is a little away from a big city.
Industry is a little away - so need to be in touch with Bay Area for jobs etc.

pros: Coworkers were great people to work with. Also the department had great working environment. The atmosphere was also very relaxed.
cons: There weren't very many hours and there was a lot of free time. Which honestly isn't a bad thing as a student, because you can work on your homework.

pros: Generally good management and office activities. Lots activities that you can be involved in your off time to make friends and have fun.
cons: Some positions can demand a lot of hours. As a city Davis can be expensive to live in and close early.

pros: Amazing people, always accommodating around my school schedule, always helping out with teaching valuable skills, receive feedback on work progress
cons: As a student, you can't work more than 20 hours per week, but it's understandable. At least it should be optional for the student if they'd like to.

review_title: Very good place to be a grad student
pros: Most students are given GSR positions which pays for tuition and gives a decent stipend. The hours are super flexible and the PI's are both supportive and knowledgeable.
cons: GSR's don't pay much, but it covers tuition and a stipend.

review_title: Great place to be a grad student
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: The resources and potential for collaborative work at UC Davis is extensive. The faculty is top-notch. The grad school environment is very interdisciplinary, and there are a lot of active student groups and extension work on campus.
cons: Difficult to find funding sometimes - TAships are available but they are competitive and leave little time to conduct your own research.

pros: There's lots of teaching experience that looks great on a resume and gives you plenty of time to learn better pedagogy, but the management could be better.
cons: Exceptional workloads, grading and expectations on top of a full school load.  Be prepared to become a workaholic, though you'd have to be one to get in to the program.

review_title: I learned a lot that will help me out in industry.
pros: Davis is a great school to go to because of the campus itself, the excellent professors, and the prestige of its many programs.
cons: It's in a college town. The summer's are hot, and the winters are freezing. Research oriented, which is bad for classes, but good for undergrad research.

review_title: Beautiful environment for study, work, and meet the future generation.
pros: This city is full of people with great minds and everyone appear to be very friendly. Definitely one of the best environments any employee can ever imagine.
cons: Working in the academia, unlike regular industries, have little effect towards the future position. This is more suitable for people that would want to stay as teacher or professor.

pros: Communication was great, boss was really understanding of me as a student. Made my own hours and never had to work more than I wanted.
cons: Won't really have a great setup for design work. If you have your own laptop, it would probably be better than what they provide for you.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: Professors are very nice. very famous professors. Some from MIT and most professors are not pushy at all. Algthough some are pushy
cons: The university is not so famous for those want to get a facuty position University is not so rich .

pros: its good to work in the university, safe city to live too. providing good enviroment for rearch, very unforgetable experience.
cons: less of pressure, limited space for development and salary. Not suitable for the people with aggressive and self chanllenged personalities. less paid.

review_title: Postdoctoral experience was great.  Health coverage was excellent.
pros: Working at UC Davis provides a stimulating set of people to interact with, a really great small-town feel, and excellent health benefits, along with a relatively lower cost of living in comparison with the bay area.
cons: Cons include feeling somewhat isolated from a larger city and living among a relatively homogeneous population of people, with respect to culture and ethnicity.

review_title: Great place to live and work
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Davis, CA
pros: UC Davis is a good university.  The city of Davis is a great place to live; it has a small town feel with all the benefits of living close to the state capitol, Sacramento.
cons: As a postdoc, your experience will be heavily dependent on the professor you work for; some professors can be more demanding than others.

pros: Great amount of learning to do. The job is very rewarding, the people are incredibly close-knit and accepting. The job itself is lax.
cons: Like many jobs, it requires interacting with people who do bring stupid questions rather consistently.

review_title: Worked at the UCD Vet Med central services and Loved working there!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Davis, CA
pros: Matt is amazing and works really well around your school schedule. The customers are all really friendly and so are the vendors.
cons: None that I can think of. I really enjoyed my job. I guess if I had more work that I could help with, that would be nice.

review_title: I went here for grad school, your experience probably depends entirely on your program.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Davis, CA
pros: I had a great time as a Teaching Assistant and Instructor over the summers. I learned a lot in my first year courses.
cons: It is difficult to rate the university as a whole as if it were a business. My graduate program in particular has a terrible graduation rate for women.

review_title: Not the worst, but could be better
job_title: Clinical Nurse II in Sacramento, CA
pros: Teaching doctors how to treat nurses and patients, collegial atmosphere, good benefits. My coworkers are the only reason I go to work most days, that, and the paycheck.
cons: Management has interesting ideas of how things should go. Don't really appreciate their resources--everyone is expendable. Do more with less seems to be the plan for them.

review_title: Great graduate student environment. Lots a support and top labs to join.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: Small class size, great faculty mentors. Research labs are collaborative and often work together across disciplines. Lots of additional resources available through university core labs.
cons: Cost of living in Davis, CA is expensive and parking on campus is also expensive. Graduate course work included some classes that could use better organization.

review_title: Grad student working at UC Davis experience
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Davis, CA
pros: UC Davis is good at research.  People here are focus on their specialization and highly motivated.  Encouragement for work are common and people are well paid.
cons: Not very good at teaching generally and profs from their own fields are usually not offer classes, however, give class from what they not best for.

review_title: UC Davis provides a great opportunity for many students to work in a relevant field.
pros: Caters to a variety of majors. Many different positions throughout major departments. Opportunities to bounce around. Process to get hired is quick.
cons: Not a lot of advertising for jobs and internships available. Those with internal connections have an upper-hand.

pros: It helps me to pay in state tuition so that it is really a high level salary. And it helps me to know about University of California undergraduate study situation. Get familiar with professor and undergraduate students.
cons: The work is very easy and just takes me little time to do it so it does not help me to improve myself.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Davis, CA
pros: Team oriented environment. Departments are fairly well structured. Great benefits. Many people are lifetime employees.
cons: Often high pressure at the beginning of each term. Some departments have been downsized leading to increased workload for other employees.

job_title: Loss Prevention Associate in Davis, CA
pros: Company is great. People are great.  Management is very good.  They are very lenient with class schedules and working with students to have the best experience.
cons: Hours are very limited due to large amount of employees.  There should be a lot more benefits of working for UCD stores but i guess what they do is good enough

pros: Exposure to cutting edge technologies including High Performance Computing.  Work with best thinkers in many fields and the brightest students.
cons:
Advancement on campus is hard.  You usually have to post out to another department to advance.

State bureaucracy can stifle initiatives and good ideas.

pros: Amazing benefits and...bonus....you can never be fired!  So, job security is amazing.  Tuituion reimbursement is also a plus if you can afford to take time off work to take classes.
cons: Pay is low.  Work is demanding.  Senior management, especially if they bring in a lot of money to the university, is so corrupt.

review_title: Review of Member Service Attendent at ARC
job_title: Member Service Attendant in Davis, CA
pros: Easy to get shifts traded. Good community of people that I work with. Pretty laid back work enviroment
cons: Early mornings and late nights. Does not give you a huge amount of specific work experience. Rude patrons

job_title: Computer Room Consultant in Davis, CA
pros: Great campus job, you can choose your work hours. Doesn't require prior knowledge of computers (they train you on the job). Great managers, fun place to work, pay is good for a campus position, with promotions
cons: Requires at least 12 hours a week, so can be hard to balance if you have a lot of hard classes.

review_title: My position is not valued by the organization.
pros: I have had the opportunity to meet many wonderful and dedicated employees who are hardworking and passionate about UC Davis.
cons: Senior management treats people like a number. They preach a culture of growing their own talent but do not follow through regardless of how much initiative you show.

pros: work around your schedule, paid prep time every week, relatively high paying for an on campus job ($14.67/hr)
cons: requires high grades in ALL of a courses progression (ie to tutor chemistry, must do well in 2A, 2B, and 2C)

pros: Interesting research topic, with a broad range of applications.  Students can work flexible hours pretty much as many hours as they can handle.
cons: Can be very tedious work, with hours on end staring through a microscope. Field opportunities are limited.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Sacramento, CA
pros: Stability, Many perks with free lunches and employee appreciation, reviews conducted regularly, professional organization
cons: Over worked in most departments, upper level executives make too much money when students are expected to pay more and more for tuition...

review_title: It was a big disappointment. This review is for C.L.A.S. department only!
pros: excellent benefits, okay pay for the work being done (possibly unsafe/unhealthy working conditions)
cons: minimal training, micro-managing, no growth opportunities, boring, no communication between management, monotonous, repetitive work

pros: Cutting edge, working with students, faculty and the frontiers of great research!
cons: UC undergoing considerable administrative changes in an effort to consolidate, reduce costs and get out of a 1950's business model.

review_title: Good benefits, ok pay, large employer, environment varies wildly between departments.
pros:
Benefits are good, especially health
Many departments to choose from
Parking is not bad for a college campus
Bike friendly campus.
cons:
Work environment varies wildly between departments
Pay can be meh.
Benefits are not as nice as they were in 2010
Need more IT but-in from campus management

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Davis, CA
pros:
Largely politics free department
You defend your dissertation proposal instead of your finished work
Light coursework requirements
TAships are nearly always available
cons:
Too much variability in requirements for big milestones.
Expectations for performance are not always clear
Like every graduate program, the pay is low

job_title: Student Affairs Officer in Davis, CA
pros: Work-life balance (hourly pay), campus culture, engaging colleagues and students, variety in the work, benefits, pension
cons: Compensation, inequity in payroll titles (classifications) within unit and across units, mismanagement, inefficiency, top-heavy management, lack of mobility (if you wish to stay in the same unit)

job_title: Senior Applications Developer (Programmer VI) in Davis, CA
pros: Work life balance is very well respected. Coworkers are friendly and helpful. UC system provides a generous benefits package and great retirement plan.
cons: Working style sometimes are slow-paced. It could be boring for someone. There is not much room for growth and promotion are not completely merit-based.

review_title: Co-workers are some of the best people to work with, but the work itself is mindless, busy-work
pros: Easy work and opportunities to talk and engage with guests and co-workers. Management of the MRAs are done by student employees as well, and they are very personable as well.
cons: Busy work and lots of downtime walking around the ARC pretending to be busy.

pros: As an individual tutor for the Student Academic Success Center and full-time student, this job provides the opportunity to work with a high hourly wage (much higher than minimum) and practice your communication skills.
cons: You are not guaranteed a tutee as it is on an on-demand basis. You only get a tutee if the course is in demand.

job_title: Student Research Assistant in Davis, CA
pros: Great opportunity to get experience in research. I was fortunate to work for a brilliant professor who cares for an mentors undergraduate students.
cons: The success of an RA position really depends upon which professor you work for. I once worked for a professor who did not show as much interest in my development as an academic.

pros: As a student lab assistant, I was able to work with little to no supervision because I was trusted to do my work. I worked in the Pavement Research Center at Richmond, CA which was a great location to work at.
cons: Sometimes the lab would get too chilly because it is mostly outdoors.

review_title: nice school for a grad students
pros: world-class institute, great location, easy to get a TA or RA position, nice staffs, close connection with other universities and companies in silicon valley, convenient to find a job after graduation
cons: salary is low for a RA position, expensive housing rent, less incorporation among research groups, relationship with professors is little bit tricky.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Davis, CA
pros: The benefits here are unmatched. You schedule can be flexible and the unions give employees some sense of job security.
cons: There are a lot of angry, grumpy, jaded people working here that make communication and team work difficult.

pros: Work with a great staff of scientists and engineers on very interesting projects. Work life/balance is encouraged.
cons: The University requires employees to pay extra for things like parking passes, which is kind of understandable. It can be a little bureaucratic at times. It's a state/government org which policies/budget cuts/etc can have an impact as well.

review_title: Great working environment if you love working with students.
pros: The opportunity to aid students in making academic and life changing decisions.
cons: While the variety of students and staff offers new experiences, the work often becomes repetitive. Also, student work can vary as it depends on their willingness to comply with your suggestions.

review_title: Like all jobs, it has it's pros and cons
job_title: Student Affairs Officer in Davis, CA
pros:
Great benefits
Can have fairly flexible schedule depending on your position
Lots of opportunities to move to other positions
cons:
Lots of institutionalized and cranky workers
Some employees just don't care anymore 
Reluctant to change processes
It's tough to get hired if you aren't an alum
Decentralized

pros: Very scholarly environment with grads and researchers passionate about their field of study.
cons: Not many cons - it's a student job, after all. Higher pay for the students, perhaps.

review_title: Meets standards but does not astonish you.
pros: Opportunities are general, not much restrictions.
cons: Too many unnecessary procedures and too much ridiculous competitions (B.A majors compete lab opportunities with B.S. majors) and you'll never have the resources you need.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros:
Excellent work environment, my PI is really supportive. 
Davis is a small, beautiful town and a little isolated from big cities but they still within the reachable distance. You can get good opportunities in the bay area.
cons: Weather in Summer sometimes is not very delight. Other than that, I think everything is great here.

pros: Nice people, great environment. The work and life balance is exactly where you would want it to be. People are also very willing to help and get you situated.
cons: Pay not competitive and as a result constant turnaround. People who do great work often are over qualified and move onto better opportunities

review_title: I love working for UC Davis. Great employer, great benefits.
job_title: Staff Research Associate II in Sacramento, CA
pros: The benefits at UC Davis are great. The atmosphere is relaxed and schedule is flexible. My co-workers are great too!
cons: Lower pay than industry and not many opportunities for advancement. Facilities are a bit outdated and can't always get the equipment you need because of budget concerns.

review_title: Culture of Bullying & Unfair Hiring Practices and Compensation
pros: Great benefits, vacation and sick leave, opportunities for advancement in a select few equitable, fair, ethical organizations.
cons: Campus has a reputation of keeping supervisors accused of bullying, unfair hiring practices. Many employees are retaliated against when they  report problems. Broken reporting system that sides with employer not employees.

review_title: Fantastic benefits, flexible work hours, great people
pros:
Extremely subsidized medical, dental, and vision healthcare
Good salaries, but below market
Great culture for inter-generational cooperation
The chance to work with people who truly care
cons:
Salaries below market 
Everything is slow (hiring process, new programs, administration, etc.)
Career Tracks lack definition for many disciplines

pros: The researchers are top notch yet much more relaxed than other UCs. Through the union, postdocs get a good contract with healthcare benefits and other protections.
cons: Davis rent is high for the type of town that it is. Some of the campus resources are not as good as some of the near-by Universities.

pros:
-Work with great people, 99% students
-Strong company culture
-Opportunities for promotion
-Flexible hours
-Some of the best parties in Davis
cons:
-Smell like food all day
-Early morning, late night shifts

pros: Working environment is good. Good work life balance. nice town, approximate to many activities.
cons: Career development is so so . But this more or less depends on the professor/group and projects you are working on. Another concerns is that for those doing scientific computing research, the computing facility and support on the Davis campus is limited.

pros: My experience at Davis was great. Learned a lot and had great classes, mentors, and piers. I would recommend the school to anyone
cons: Living in Davis can be tough at times, especially during the hot summer. You are your own boss in many ways so working hard is to your advantage.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: Great University, great body of professors. Campus is amazing with access to recreation and fitness areas. It is ranked as one of the top research universities in the U.S.
cons: Focuses too much on academia. Little encouragement to work in private sector as graduate student. Tuition is way to high for a state university.

pros: Great work environment and benefits.
cons: If your position becomes represented, don't expect a promotion. The union wants your monthly dues and will not work in your favor. Some people might not like a politically liberal environment.

review_title: Graduate experience, as usual, dependent on advisor
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: Top notch resources for your education, graduate student researchers have recently won the right to union representation
cons: Increasing concerns over profit motive of UC system, campus police militarization, increasing tuition, affordability of housing.

review_title: Brilliant Minds, Good Community but Hard for Grad Students
pros: Most people are generously friendly, supportive. Very intelligent and academically regious. Bikeable campus is a plus
cons: Graduate student wage is below industry standard ranging from $20k to $35k. Benefits are limited factoring in the skills and experiences of advanced Ph.D. work

review_title: UC Davis gave me the tools and skills to launch my career forward.
job_title: Student Facility Manager in Davis, CA
pros: Great work environment, helpful staff, good work hours, a good stable job
cons: A lot of bureaucracy and hurtles to get through at times

job_title: Student Assistant III in Davis, CA
pros: It was pretty mundane and general lab work. I dont think it would be anything different than any other big university. I liked the amount of knowledge obtained from the research however.
cons: Very underpayed. For students working part time it doesent feel like 8.95 an hour is sufficient to make a dent in expenses.

pros:
- great work environment
- the work you do is important and makes you feel fulfilled
- great management/ supervisors 
- flexible hours
cons:
- meetings can feel long and drawn out
- not much else to say that's negative

pros:
1. Online journal access is up-to-date and fully covered for my research.
2. Library service is awesome.
3. Teaching and mentor opportunities are provided by the Department for Postdocs.
4. Supportive for attending academy conferences.
5. Union of Postdocs play a role to protect the welfare.
cons: Living expense is higher than most of college towns

pros: It was a pleasure working with ATS at UC Davis. Having friendly supervisors and a fun job that mostly entails recording lectures made this experience worthwhile and unique.
cons: No cons, just the construction at UCD making it hard to navigate into the building at times, but that's of course temporary.

review_title: A great working community for those who never experienced working as a tutor
pros:
Beginner friendly and supportive community to work in

Provides resources that helps visualize effectiveness of your tutoring
cons: While it was not a major issue, as the community is mainly student run, some of the resources required to teach students were not ready when necessary

pros: It's unique that our community aims to abide by the Principles of Community. There are opportunities to meet  diverse staff. The town and gown relationship is very positive.
cons: Raises come few and far between.

job_title: Student Assistant III in Davis, CA
pros: Flexible schedule around my classes, those I worked with in the office were really respectful of my time as a student. Student jobs on campus are really great opportunities for busy students who are looking to make some money.
cons: No cons, truly enjoyed my experience as a student employee.

review_title: Great experience as part of the UC Davis Heavy-Ion Physics Graduate Program
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Davis, CA
pros: The heavy-ion physics group led by Daniel Cebra and Manuel Calderon is a great group with supportive advisers, and a very healthy work balance.
cons: It is definitely a long process, work is very challenging, and definitely requires a huge level of commitment.

job_title: Student Assistant At the Pro Shop in Davis, CA
pros: Really nice job on campus. It had flexible hours and each year you get a pay raise based on your performance. You worked with an awesoem group of coworkers and the discounts were really nice!
cons: Everyone is required to work on Picnic Day.

pros: Be a part of a universal do good project
cons: Crappy pay and budget cuts make having a good resume handy a necessity

review_title: Great place to work for, provides opportunities for growth.
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Davis, CA
pros: Positive and fun environment.  There are many opportunities for personal and professional growth and progress.  Company cares about its employees and provides competitive salaries and benefits.
cons: None.  Overall a positive place to work at, although some departments may be under staffed.

review_title: Large research university that is dedicated to excellence.
pros: Being able to engage with the community and engage with people from the industry. Time-off is great. Pay is fair. People are nice all around. Culture is a little aged, but getting younger.
cons: Too big and at times feels disconnected across departments and labs.

review_title: Presents many opportunities in the education world.
pros: Several different resources will enable you too create a large series of networks for future jobs. Also, very friendly people to work with.
cons: UC Davis does not have the best parking situation, it is extremely limited. Also, the campus has serious problems with budget cuts and therefore our hours.

review_title: glass ceiling without a graduate degree
pros: Nice campus easy transportation great benifits
cons: No advancement possible in general without a graduate degree and then only rarely. Low pay compared to private sector

pros: Beautiful city with lots to offer. Great professors and a very active department. Not a bad place to spend a year. Near San Francisco which is a plus.
cons: Huge school with tons and tons of undergrads. In Sacramento which is a bummer. Lots of focus on agriculture in the university. Not very good food.

job_title: Student Assistant II in Davis, CA
pros: For students, work hours are very flexible so that work and school can be managed. Students are also able to learn more about a particular job and gain invaluable experience from it.
cons: Often times, the work (general clerical duties) students do can be easily boring because it is repetitive.

pros:
-- Coworkers are students as well, making it easy to associate with one another
-- Work schedule catered to student life
-- Located on campus
-- Dynamic environment that keeps you alert
-- Interview/Resume workshops available
-- Opportunities for promotion available
-- Opportunities to cover shifts and/or get shifts covered
cons: -- Very early openings, very late closings

job_title: Teaching Assistant/Graduate Student in Davis, CA
pros: The professors that I have worked with are doing really great research.
cons: Low salary, high amounts of teaching assignments, and overall disregard for the graduate students.

pros: Lots of student activism addressing a range of on campus and off campus issues. Really talented students. Lounges are filled with students studying
cons: Political challenges and at times upper administration is afraid of confronting and or listening to the students. Need to open doors more to students.

review_title: UC Davis is a good school.
pros: The job is great and I like my PI. Pay is also good. I like the overall academic environment.
cons: Davis is a very small town and Sacramento is not great either.

pros: Mathematics Department management is friendly, organized, and attentive to individual needs. I worked as a part-time Reader and my preference for courses I am comfortable grading was always taken into account.
cons: Unstable - some quarters they didn't need any Readers, so I had to wait until another quarter.

review_title: It all depends on your P.I.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Davis, CA
pros: Depending on your boss you can have very flexible hours and the freedom to try new things. Postdocs currently have great benefits.
